Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of standing ithyphallic figure, probably Harpocrates. Harpocrates wears a robe and holds his large phallus with his right hand, whilst strangling a goose with his left. By his left foot is a round vessel. Mould-made and hollow with simple back. Thick white coating, with traces of pink and red paint. Grey-brown over-fired Nile silt with abundant mica and sand inclusions. Only bottom left part of figure is preserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Two ithyphallic Harpocrates figures from Naukratis are strangling a goose (British Museum GR1973,0501.24, Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1833). These are variants of reclining ithyphallic Harpocrates that are dated to the end of fourth and the beginning of the third century BC. This example is likely slightly later, of third and possibly second century BC.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.028) (Phase 3)
